abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Vilcanota Valley
            Rehabilitation and Management Project for Peru were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the project attempted to address a broad
            range of multi-sectoral issues ranging from cultural
            heritage preservation to regional development and provision
            of basic infrastructure services. Addressing this complex
            range of themes required multiple institutions and large
            teams on both the Bank and the Government side.
            Participatory processes only contributed to the excessive
            scope and complexity of the original design. Some activities
            required coordination among several institutions at
            different government level, such as the revisions and
            approvals of the feasibility studies. Poor
            inter-institutional coordination and communication created
            delays and often contradicting messages to the consultant.
            The Bank team supported intensive training in procurement
            and financial management but this was not done early enough
            in the project cycle and resulted in large delays in
            disbursements. The decision to prior review all contracts
            adopted during the restructuring reduced procurement risk
            but also created substantial delays for the Borrower while
            waiting for Bank no objections.
